passages.text: Japan and the US have agreed to a \(15\%\) reciprocal tariff and a \(15\%\) tariff on autos and auto parts. Although an actionable executive order has yet to be issued, in this report we provide our take on the impact of these tariffs on Japan's macro economy and corporate earnings, based on what the Japanese government believes to be the details of the agreement at this point. We also discuss the mechanism and potential of the \(\) 550\(bn in investments Japan has agreed to make in the US.

Japan Economics - The shift to \(15\%\) tariffs should have virtually no impact on Japan's GDP. However, the agreement will ease uncertainty for Japanese companies, which may encourage them to pass tariff costs on to customers and make capital investments. At the same time, we think in the latter half of 2025 the global economy (including the US) will undergo a reflexive pullback in demand (following the pre- tariff spike), and we believe the BoJ will need to assess the impact of this before it hikes interest rates. We still expect a rate hike in January 2026. We think foreign direct investment in the US will continue, mainly in growth fields like data centers and biotech, but this depends on the US macroeconomic performance. The \(\) 550\(bn in investments will likely be implemented in a flexible and long- term manner. Regardless of the pace of implementation, however, the massive\) \ \(1.5\) trn in combined investments by Japan, the EU, and South Korea could have the effect of supporting US trend inflation and neutral interest rates.

Japan Rates and FX - While it is natural to view the \(\) 550\(bn in investments in the US as a long- term objective, if investments in the US are to truly increase to such a scale some kind of USD funding measure (e.g., the establishment of an investment and lending facility by the JBIC or similar institution) may be necessary. Meanwhile, the US- Japan trade agreement is likely to create yen- depreciation pressure near term as Japanese share prices rise in a worldwide risk- on environment, offsetting yen- appreciation pressure. However, we expect yen- appreciation pressure to prevail as investors increasingly price in BoJ normalization. We maintain our view that the USD/JPY rate will fall toward the\) \ \(140 / \Phi\) level in October- December. Meanwhile, we expect the 10y JGB yield to rise to around \(1.7\%\) over the next six months or so, while we believe the 30y yield will remain at a high level (c3.0%).

Japan Equity Strategy - With this agreement we think 1) the negative impact of tariffs on corporate earnings will be smaller than previously expected, 2) valuations are more likely to expand thanks to the elimination of uncertainty, and 3) capital inflows from outside Japan are likely to accelerate. All of these factors strengthen the medium/long- term bullish scenario for Japanese stocks. If the Japanese government adopts measures to encourage increased direct investment into the US it could be a positive for Japanese stocks in general. Our mid- 2006 targets are 3,400 for TOPIX and 47,000 for the Nikkei 225. For tariff earnings impact by sector please see Figure 8.

Japan Equity Research - While a \(15\%\) tariff is a heavy burden, we believe Japan's major industries could minimize cost increases by maintaining existing systems for exporting to the US rather than relocating production there. Japanese companies have yet to announce any significant deals related to the \(\) 550\(bn in investments, but it's relatively easy to envision such deals accumulating over the next ten years in the form of M&A, factory investments, and technology development investments. Carefully considered business investment could enable Japanese companies to emit RoIC deterioration to some extent. Please see Figure 13 for a summary of our sector thoughts.

Citi Research is a division of Citigroup Global Markets Inc. (the "Firm"), which does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the Firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. Certain products (not inconsistent with the author's published research) are available only on Citi's portals.

The US and Japan agreed on July 23 to \(15\%\) for both reciprocal tariffs and the tariff on autos and auto parts (the latter being made up of an additional tariff of \(12.5\%\) and a base tariff of \(2.5\%\) ). There are no volume restrictions, and the fact that auto tariffs on a major auto exporting nation were lowered is notable. The Japanese government announcement also says agreement was reached that if there are new tariffs imposed on semiconductors and pharmaceuticals in the future, the rate equal to the lowest on any country will apply to Japan. Japan will increase the allotment to imports from the US within the minimum access provision for rice. It also agreed to buy \(\) 8.0bn\(of agricultural products, including corn, soybeans, fertilizer, and ethanol. Purchases of defense equipment and aircraft were said to be within the current scope and not new purchases. Japan will review the preferential treatment of fuel - cell vehicles (FCVs) over electric vehicles, and exempt US passenger cars with high safety standards from testing.

The agreement also included \(\) 550bn\(in investment in the US, although no period for this to be achieved was specified. The investment will be in nine areas of importance to economic security, including energy, semiconductors, critical minerals and shipbuilding. A facility of the same amount will be established for investments, loans and loan guarantees by government financial institutions. The distribution of returns on the investment between Japan and the US will be 1:9. Alaskan LNG projects will be considered. The EU, South Korea, and others have also pledged investment in the US, and the scheme will be similar to that advocated by the Japanese government in that there will be small amounts of equity investment and most will be financing and government guarantees.

The Minister in charge of Economic Revitalization Ryosei Akazawa, who was responsible for the negotiations, indicated that he expected the lowering of auto tariffs to be in mid- September, and said that he had confirmed with the US that the reciprocal tariff rate would not be imposed in addition to the existing tariff rate. However, uncertainties remain regarding when the agreement will take effect and even whether it will actually be implemented. There is also a big gap between the understandings of the US and Japanese governments when it comes to the scheme for the \(\) 550bn\(investment. A July 23 White House factsheet says that the investment will be "at President Trump's direction," and could be used as the discretion as a type of "signing bonus." Minister Akazawa, however, as said the pledge was to invest in the US at a time that would benefit Japan. Amid this uncertainty, the US and Japanese governments appear to be considering the establishment of a forum for discussion of the investment facility (Reuters, August 13) and creating a joint document for the US- Japan investment agreement (Nikkei, August 26).

President Trump said on August 6 that he would impose a \(100\%\) tariff on semiconductors and has indicated that he would raise that on pharmaceuticals in stages to \(250\%\) (as of this writing). However, if companies express an intention to manufacture products that use semiconductors in the US, that company (or

On August 18, the US government expanded the tariff on steel and aluminum to include 407 derivative products. This will affect a broad range of capital goods, including construction and agricultural machinery, industrial robots, machine tools, and bearings. If a \(50\%\) tariff is imposed on these products without exception, it could be a potential problem for Japanese companies that export products that contain large amounts of steel, and this will not yet have been factored into companies' outlooks for the impact of tariffs.

A shift from the previous reciprocal tariff of \(10\%\) and auto tariff of \(25\%\) to a reciprocal tariff of \(15\%\) and an auto tariff of \(15\%\) will make very little difference on the impact on GDP (Figure 1). This is because the rise in the reciprocal tariff and the decline in the auto tariff will offset each other. However, the agreement will reduce uncertainty for companies and may encourage them to pass tariff costs on in export prices as well as to increase capital expenditure. There will be a focus particularly on price pass- through for tariff costs by Japanese auto assemblers in the US market (please see the Autos section for more). This is because it will have implications for US inflation.

It is good news for Japan that uncertainty regarding tariffs has diminished and that the negative impact on auto companies, which could have also impacted wage hikes next year, has also been reduced. Despite the imposition of tariffs, Japan maintained positive growth in April- June for a fifth consecutive quarter, and this was partly because of support from auto assemblers' absorbing tariff costs and a last- minute swelling in export demand for high- tech products. We expect a negative reaction to last- minute demand to emerge around the world in H2, and the BoJ will probably feel the need to confirm this impact before hiking. January next year remains our base scenario for the next rate hike.

The Ishiba government remains in power despite the ruling coalition having lost three consecutive major elections. We think PM Ishiba remains in power because there was a need that there be no change in the members of the negotiating party that secured the reduction in auto tariffs, and because if the LDP elected a new president it may be forced to accept a consumption tax cut in order to win the Diet vote for prime minister. The number of LDP Diet members and prefectural representatives that want the PM to resign is getting close to a majority. Even if the PM avoids an early vote for LDP president, the autumn Diet session could be very difficult for him. Delays to the reduction in auto tariffs would mean a risk that the PM is forced out.

In addition to the tariff agreement, Japan will not change its total import quota for rice but will increase the US allocation by reducing those to other nations, so it will not affect Japanese farmers. In auto exports, Japan will exempt vehicles imported from the US that have high safety standards from testing, but this will likely promote the reverse import of Japanese vehicles assembled in the US. US assemblers' vehicles do not sell well in Japan because the size, fuel consumption, and customer service, etc. are not attractive to Japanese consumers, and this is unlikely to change.

We think the Japanese government will simply establish a facility for \(\) 550\(bn of investment, financing and financing guarantees. The actual investment amounts will be set autonomously by Japanese companies according to the economic benefit. However, how much will actually be executed is not clear. It is not clear whether the\) \ \(550\) bn will be in greenfield investment alone, or whether it will include M&A deals and the reinvestment of earnings. However, to date US macroeconomic conditions have been important to direct investment in the US (Figure 2). The performance of the US has been well ahead of the rest of the world in terms of GDP growth rates since the COVID pandemic and the development of AI and biotech, so it has attracted FDI from around the world' (Figure 3).
Figure 2. Japan's outstanding direct investment in the US and US GDP (YoY change)

According to our analysts, Japanese companies are likely to invest aggressively in the US in high growth areas such as Al data centers, biotech plants, and biotech ventures (Figure 13). Japanese companies may also increase investment in the areas they are strongest, such as social infrastructure and entertainment. We see little likelihood that under a tariff rate of \(15\%\) industries that would face high personnel costs and steel prices in the US (such as autos and machinery) and industries that are highly integrated in Japan (such as autos and semiconductor production equipment) would shift significant amounts of production to the US.

The Minister in charge of Economic Revitalization Ryosei Akazawa said that it would be desirable if the \(\) 550bn\(figure could be achieved by the end of President Trump's term, but this would be challenging. In 2024, direct investment into the US by Japan totaled\) \ \(750bn\) , and it has grown by around \(\) 38bn\(a year on average over the past ten years, so a more realistic assumption would be that it would take ten years (annual growth of\) \ \(55bn\) ). As seen in infrastructure investment under the Biden administration, labor supply constraints within the US would make it difficult to achieve total investment by Japan, the EU, and South Korea combined of \(\) 1.5\(trn in a short time. Regardless of the pace, such a huge investment would tend to support trend inflation and the neutral interest rate in the US.

At the same time, Figure 2 indicates that FDI from Japan slows when the macroeconomic performance of the US deteriorates. At such a time the US government could well criticize Japan for making insufficient investment and, as indicated by US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, there would be a risk that tariffs would be increased. Also, if the Republicans lose the midterm elections next year, expectations that tariffs could be abolished or reduced in the future may cause a slowdown in investment in the US. As we discuss above, we do not see a tariff rate
of \(15\%\) as sufficient to encourage a major transfer of production by Japanese companies, and some companies may decide to scrap production- transfer plans due to such reasons.

We think the domains that will be invested in will be the nine specified in the US- Japan agreement, but it is unclear as yet where the most rapid growth will be. FDI balances as of 2024 show that within manufacturing, the highly weighted sectors with the most rapid growth in recent years are chemicals (including pharmaceuticals), transport equipment, and computers & electronic components, which would be in line with the nine areas in the agreement (Figure 4). Assuming for simplicity that the shares of cumulative investment remain as they were in 2024 and investment grows by \(\) 550\(bn over the next 10 years, this would imply growth of\) \ \(775bn\) in chemicals (including pharmaceuticals), \(\) 55bn\(in transport equipment, and\) \ \(22bn\) in computers and electronic components.

In non- manufacturing (mainly wholesale trade and finance), there has been steady growth in FDI, and the same extrapolation would imply growth of \(\) 316bn\(over the next 10 years (Figure 5). In the ICT industry SoftBank Group has announced it will invest\) \ \(500bn\) over four years in the construction of data centers in conjunction with US companies, so it could play a central role. Our sector analysts outline the investment opportunities in each sector later in this report.

Cabinet Minister Ryosei Akazawa said that of the \(\) 550bn\(, investment would account for no more than\) 1\% - 2\% \(. However, most of the remainder, which will be provided via financing and guarantees to Japanese companies (both public and private sector), will ultimately flow to the US in the form of investment. In this respect, US investment could potentially cause the selling of the JPY and buying of the USD. If the Japanese government established a facility via which companies could obtain USD funding, however, there could be the option to invest in the US without buying the USD on the market. The selling of the JPY due to the rapid growth in direct investment by Japanese companies has been one reason for structural JPY weakness over more than ten years now, but there could in fact be a decline in JPY selling. FDI by Japanese companies is not only in the US, but if the Japanese government established a financing facility for US investment only, investment in Asia and Europe could decline, and this could have a negative effect on Asian and European currencies.

The Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC) would likely play a central role in a \(\) 550bn\(financing facility. The JBIC's total assets as of March 2025 were around\) \ \(20\) trn, of which financing was about \(\) 15trn\(. On the funding side, borrowings were about\) \ \(8\) trn and bonds some \(\) 6trn\(, with net assets such as government equity some\) \ \(3\) trn. Achieving lending of \(\) 80trn\((\\( 550bn)\) in its current state would be difficult for the JBIC, so some form of government support would be necessary. The MoF already has foreign currency lending to JBIC (borrowing by JBIC from the government). In addition to foreign currency reserves of around\) \ \(1.3\) trn, the government also has some \(\) 36.3bn\(of "other foreign currency assets" in the Foreign Exchange Fund Special Account, and almost all of this is lent to JBIC (it is included in the above\) \ \(8\) trn of JBIC borrowings). Options include 1) increasing foreign currency lending to JBIC (this would cause a superficial decline in foreign currency reserves), or 2) increase the capital bases of JBIC and Nippon Export and Investment Insurance (NEXI), with investment in kind from foreign currency reserves a possibility.

When the Abe government was attempting to negotiate the return of the disputed Kuril Islands, there was a proposal for Japan Organization for Metals and Energy Security (JOGMEC) to invest in Rosneft. When planning the US investment this time also, it may be necessary to look to government entities in relation to the development of Alaskan gas fields. The required project funding for the development of Alaskan gas including the laying of pipelines is estimated at \(\) 50bn\(around\) \ \(7\) trn). We think Japan would not have to bear the entire amount, but
foreign currency reserves are likely to be used in some way in this development of Alaskan gas.

For the bond market, the focus is the breakdown of the \(\) 550bn\(of loans and investment and specifically how the government will be involved. The issues are how and when funds will be raised from the market, and the amount. That it is not only yen but also foreign currencies that will be required increases the complexity. However, regardless of whether the form of the exit is investment, loans or guarantees, a commensurate amount of foreign currency will be required.

The first option for foreign currency freely available to the government is the Foreign Exchange Fund Special Account. The balance was a huge \(\) 1,304.4bn\(as of end - July 2025. However, much of this is invested in Treasuries. We do not think that reducing that investment balance would be acceptable in negotiations with the US. If forex intervention is necessary then a decline in the balance could not be avoided, but we doubt that the US would readily agree. We think the US would likely send a message that the BoJ should hike its policy rate before the yen depreciates excessively. In any case, the government would be able to freely use only the part of the Foreign Exchange Fund Special Account that is held as cash and deposits.

As of end- July, the BoJ had deposits with other central banks and the BIS of \(\) 161.3bn\(. This item grew rapidly between CY14 H2 and CY16, and at the same time the liability item of RRP with foreign public institutions also increased sharply. We think most of the growth at that time was in Japan's foreign currency reserves. If this is used as a source of funding, it would mean only a change in how excess funds of the Japanese government are managed, and no additional funding would be required. From the US perspective there would be a decline in the amount of interest it pays Japan, but no impact on supply/demand for Treasuries, so there would be benefits to both sides. Some\) \ \(100bn\) could be provided in this way.
some funds in yen via the Fiscal Loans and Investments Program Special Account. This would put widening pressure on the XCCY basis market

When guarantees are made for private sector companies, it is the relevant company that will procure funding. If the company has ample dollar liquidity, it would use this to invest or it could fund investment with future earnings. In this case, the impact on the market would be that the amount not swapped into yen would increase and potentially cause yen depreciation. However, if the investment is large there will be insufficient funding available, and the weighting of debt financing will increase, in which case Japanese banks will play a major role. However, it is not clear at this point whether there is this much demand for funds. Bank activity is likely to come after demand has been confirmed, and firstly in the form of medium- to long- term yen swaps, and after that as corporate bonds. Traditionally, funding is often for around five years, but the potential impact on longer maturities cannot be ignored. Nevertheless, the XCCY basis market been stable, and there appears to be no tightness in dollar funding. It cannot be known when flows will occur, but risk- on sentiment and the strength of equities appear to be causing tightening in the basis. Even so, if flows increase then issuance by government financial institutions would likely cause change to the valuation of the JGB \(\) ASW\$

It will not be necessary to immediately find funding of \(\) 550\(bn, and it will not be that the government bears the entire risk, so it should not soon affect the credit rating of JGBs. The market will not become wary of risk until it starts to become conscious of defaults. We think the risk will be larger for guarantees and lending to overseas companies than to big Japanese companies. In the near term, we think the FY3/27 budget will have a bigger impact on the credit rating.

It is unclear how much of the proposed \(\) 550\(bn investment and loans to the US will be realized, so it will be difficult for the market to factor it in as a realistic possibility. As we discuss above, we do not expect dramatic changes in US or Japanese interest rates over the next few months. In a globally risk - off environment the US - Japan trade agreement is likely to boost Japanese equities, and this will put downward pressure on the yen that offsets the upward pressure. We expect the USDJPY to remain in the\) \ \(145 / \Phi - \Phi 148 / \Phi\) range. However, as BoJ monetary policy normalization continues to be priced in, an outlook that US and Japan could coordinate FX policy as well may emerge and consequently begin to strengthen the JPY. When the Fed resumes rate cuts and the rate US- Japan differential shrinks, a JPY recovery should be more apparent. In the medium term we think the JPY will likely strengthen if US and Japanese equity markets adjust lower, even temporarily. We maintain the view that the USDJPY will decline to\) \ \(140 / \Phi\) in October- December.

We expect the yield on the 10y JGB to rise to around \(1.7\%\) over the next six months, but we also expect a slowing in the pace of increase in super- long interest rates, which have continued to lead the overall interest- rate rise. We think the 30y yield, for example, will plateau at around \(3.0\%\) . Life insurers and other domestic investors are likely to steadily reduce overseas investment, so underlying supply/demand for the yen should improve. For at least the next few months we believe the yen is likely to appreciate.

We previously wrote that that we believe FX policy would be discussed confidentially in US- Japan trade negotiations. While James Baker, the then- Treasury Secretary who led the 1985 Plaza Accord, was originally a jurist, current Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent has long experience in the markets. We believe he is not supportive of correcting USD strength via FX intervention, but rather would prioritize BoJ monetary policy normalization and the likely JPY recovery that would result. Also, Mr. Bessent might focus on how to utilize Japanese foreign reserves, which have reached \(\) 1.3\$ tn. While there are concerns about US government bond supply/demand, one concrete measure in the near term could be the Japanese MoF extending the duration of its bond purchases. We think the Japanese government has converted USD cash obtained via US Treasury coupon payments partially into EUR and the like. However, it is possible that diversification into other currencies will diminish moving forward.

Following the tariff agreement, we think three factors increase the likelihood of a longer- term bullish scenario for Japanese stocks: 1) outlook for the negative earnings impact of tariffs to be less than previously expected; 2) increased prospects for valuations to expand with the elimination of uncertainty; 3) possible acceleration of fund inflows from overseas. That Japanese equities rose rapidly to all- time highs after the agreement was reached is not surprising given these points.

Based on the agreed- upon tariff rates we estimate the direct impact on overall corporate earnings in Japan (not considering cost pass- through and impact on US economy) improves by around 4ppt. Also considering a weaker yen than initially expected, we look for Japanese companies to maintain EPS growth in FY2025 (Figure 8). We think important factors for the stock market are that the negative impact on EPS is less than expected, and that reaching an agreement in tariff talks eliminates future uncertainty. Looking back at 2020, when corporate earnings deteriorated sharply due to the pandemic, we can see that even as the earnings outlook deteriorated, investors moved to factor in a future earnings recovery because the government's policy response raised expectations for a return to normal (Figure 9). If a similar pattern unfolds now, even if earnings estimates continue to be revised down to reflect the short- term impact of tariffs we think share prices are likely to rise on future expectations.

In previous reports we cited a good supply/demand environment and sustained buying of Japanese stocks by overseas investors as reasons for a strong recovery in share prices despite an uncertain environment for Japanese stocks. In addition, we have noted three reasons for the continued inflow of overseas funds into Japanese stocks: 1) Japanese stocks are lagging and offer attractive valuations versus global stocks; 2) a decline in forex sensitivity for Japanese stocks and EPS makes global investors more likely to buy Japanese stocks when the yen holds flat or appreciates gradually; 3) fund inflows into stock markets have strengthened overall due to ongoing high growth in the global money supply and to difficulty buying bonds owing to concerns about inflation and financial deterioration. We believe the current agreement between Japan and the US ahead of other major countries could contribute to relative reassurance about Japanese stocks, and we think fund inflows from overseas could accelerate.

Amid a recovery for Japanese stocks since mid- April, high- quality stocks with high valuations have shown strong recoveries, while economic- sensitive value stocks have lagged behind. In terms of stock selection, investors have shown a strong preference for reassuring stocks amid an uncertain outlook for tariff talks and the economy. Amidst expectations for uncertainty to decline due to the Japan- US tariff agreement and Japanese stocks to continue rising, we think lagging sectors and stocks are more likely to catch up. Moreover, if long- term interest rates remain high on concerns about financial deterioration, we would expect a shift from high valuation to low valuation.

As is evident in the discussion thus far, the \(\) 550bn\(figure for investment from Japan into the US is in essentially a medium - to long - term goal. Even so, if financing and guarantees are provided by JBIC, etc., there could be increased direct investment in the US by Japanese companies. Of Japanese FDI, 37% of the outstanding amount and 43% of recent flows are direct investment in the US. In addition, within total Japanese FDI around half is M&A deals (Figure 10). So increased direct investment in the US could lead to increased growth not only in local capital expenditure but also M&A deals. Overseas M&A deals by Japanese companies have been growing in recent years (Figure 11), and on average returns on the share prices of companies announcing M&A deals has been positive over the

medium- to long- term. When a share price has reacted positively in the three months after the announcement, in particular, valuations have tended to continue to expand thereafter (Figure 12). If the new agreement means that the Japanese government puts in place measures to promote direct investment in the US, it should be positive for Japanese equities overall.

According to our estimates (CY24), Japanese production accounted for \(73\%\) of US sales at Mitsubishi Motor (100% in CY25), \(53\%\) at Mazda, \(44\%\) at Subaru, \(24\%\) at Toyota, and \(17\%\) at Nissan. If tariff rates shift to a manageable level, we think it will help to focus more attention on the positive effects of the easing in environmental regulations. We also note that Japanese automakers could gain a relative edge, depending on the agreements reached by other countries.

For share price implications we see the agreement as positive for the autos and auto parts sectors overall. We think it is positive for Mazda, Subaru, Toyota, MMC, and Nissan but above all we think the benefits could be significant for Mazda, which seems to be on track to generate profits. We think the agreement could also be positive for Honda in that it means less concern about US demand.

Among the vehicles sold by Japanese manufacturers in the US, the ratio of locally produced to imported vehicles is roughly half and half. Approximately \(45\%\) of the imports come from Japan, \(28\%\) from Mexico, and \(27\%\) from Canada. The additional tariff on imports from Japan has been set at \(12.5\%\) , while the rates for Mexico and Canada are still under negotiation. We think the overall tariff rate for all Japanese imports can be reasonably estimated at around \(12.5\%\) after factoring in exemptions under the USMCA.

Given that the cost at US customs accounts for approximately \(70\%\) of the local retail price and the local production rate is about \(50\%\) , we estimate the tariff will require Japanese manufacturers to raise prices by around \(4.4\%\) , or about \(5.9\%\) when components are included.

When the actual US selling price of automobiles in January 2020 is indexed to 100, it stood at around 125 in 2025, representing an average annual increase of about \(5\%\) . Consumers are relatively accustomed to price hikes since model year updates (opportunities to raise prices) occur annually. We thus think an increase of \(6\%\) could be absorbed over a period of about two years.

Since the powertrain transition will require new production facilities, we think investment in plants making batteries, motors, inverters, and other components will primarily be local, which should drive some investment in the US. However, automakers are currently trimming their investment plans in response to Trump administration efforts to scale back incentives for EVs.

We estimate a \(\) 55bn\((\text {8tn}) investment in the US transport equipment sector would require projects equivalent to 1.2mn battery electric vehicles (BEVs). This number is based on Honda's announcement in April 2024 of a CAD15bn (\) \ \(1.6tn\) ) EV project in Canada (currently postponed) that aimed to produce 240,000 EVs annually and included investments in key components such as batteries and materials. We note that if such investments are undertaken in the US, they would also include some investments in electronic components and the chemical sector.

The figure of 1.2mn BEVs corresponds to roughly \(30\%\) of Japanese automakers' US sales. We think this would be a challenging target for 2030, but it could be discussed as a plan for 2035 given the potential for a further shift to EVs by then.
Potential for US investment

The US market accounts for \(c5\%\) of all sales by Japanese machinery manufacturers, with most exported from Japan. However, it is unclear how many companies will increase investment in the US in the wake of the trade agreement. Komatsu has indicated it is unlikely to boost output in the US (primarily due to high steel costs), and Makita also appears reluctant to invest more in its Georgia plant. However, Kubota may increase its local production ratio in the US market over the next 12- 24 months, and Hitachi Construction Machinery might commit to local production of hydraulic excavators.

Along with Q2 results in early August, Kubota said the estimated (gross) impact of the \(15\%\) tariff on Japanese exports and \(30\%\) tariff on exports from China would be about \(\) 35bn\(for the five months to December), with a full - year impact closer to\) \ \(80bn\) . We think Kubota may provide further details on plans to expand production at current sites in Kansas and Georgia next February.

At HCM, higher costs from the tariff regime are estimated at \(\) 8.6bn\(, a surprisingly low figure as all equipment sold under the Hitachi brand is imported from Japan. Management at HCM has made no comment regarding establishing an assembly plant in the US, but with strategy focused on expanding the Americas business we would expect an announcement regarding the establishment of such a plant in the US within the next two to three years.

In contrast, Komatsu imports about half of all equipment sold in the US from various plants in Japan, Thailand, and Brazil. Komatsu estimates the impact of the tariffs this year at around \(\) 75bn\(, but as noted above, management is reluctant to expand its US manufacturing footprint due to the relatively high cost of steel and labor.

At KHI, tariffs are expected to raise costs by \(\) 18.0bn\(, of which\) \ \(15.7bn\) is attributed to the power sports & engine (PS&E) division. To mitigate this impact, the company plans to raise prices by \(\) 8.3bn\(, with PS&E accounting for at least\) \ \(6.0bn\) of this.

Although not directly tied to the recent US- Japan trade agreement, Yaskawa Electric has already announced plans to invest approximately \(\) 26bn\(over the next 5 - 10 years to boost its local production ratio in the US (see here for details).

Additionally, there have been some notable announcements of US acquisitions by Hoshizaki, which acquired Structural Concepts Corporation for \(\) 54bn\(and Misumi Group, which acquired Fictiv for\) \ \(50.1bn\) .

We expect the changes in US tariffs on Japan to have a limited effect on this sector. There are relatively few companies producing in Japan for export to the US, with most exporting from Asia or producing locally in the US. It has thus been thought from the outset that tariffs would have a minimal impact. We also think the current willingness of customers (particularly B2B suppliers and companies involved in building social infrastructure) to accept price increases will be supportive. We anticipate a number of changes as tariff discussions progress and ultimately reach a resolution. These include 1) weaker demand or economic stagnation due to higher prices for products and services, 2) reduced demand in reaction to a last- minute surge in purchases before tariffs were imposed in earnest, and 3) increased demand as companies undertake new business ventures or planned investments they had been hesitant to implement.

In the industrial and consumer electronics sectors, we expect Mitsubishi Electric, Sharp, and Yamaha will report significant improvements in their profit outlooks because of the lower tariffs. We estimate the reduced rate will boost company EPS forecasts by \(1.1\%\) at Mitsubishi Electric, \(9.1\%\) at Sharp, and \(3.4\%\) at Yamaha. When announcing earnings for the Apr- Jun quarter, Sony lowered its estimate of the tariffs' full- year impact from \(\) 100bn\(to\) \ \(70bn\) , while Mitsubishi Electric reduced its estimate from \(\) 70bn\(to\) \ \(30bn\) .

Hitachi's social infrastructure business is centered on the power grid and railways and represents a significant part of its US operations. Given our expectation of a long- term structural increase in demand, coupled with the fact that the current competitive environment makes it relatively easy to pass on the cost of tariffs, we think the \(15\%\) tariff will have a minimal impact. The firm's high local production ratio will also limit the direct impact of tariffs. IT services are another core business for Hitachi in the US. As software and services such as local systems development are exempt from the reciprocal tariffs, the impact will likely be restricted to storage products and certain types of hardware. Hitachi has experience with Ytn- scale M&A projects in the US and may pursue more deals as momentum for Japanese investment in the US grows. The company CFO has previously commented that there are strict hurdle rate requirements when making investment decisions, but we think it will be important to keep a close eye on the valuation of future acquisitions.

Apart from the impact of tariffs, we see potential for Mitsubishi Electric to pursue large M&A deals in the US. The company secured a fresh Ytn M&A budget this May. Given management's focus on boosting RoIC, large deals that are likely to add significantly to goodwill or intangible assets will have to be closely scrutinized to determine whether they will enhance equity valuations. As the firm has numerous
cyclical businesses, including factory automation, we believe a successful track record of profit growth through M&A could result in a higher valuation for the stock.

Sony's US operations are among the group's most important. We think they could come up for discussion in the context of tariff impacts and Japan's investment in the US and play a significant role in this area. Entertainment content (games, music, and movies)—the firm's biggest business—is not subject to tariffs, but consumer electronics such as gaming consoles and TVs will be directly affected. However, Sony has rapidly shifted production of its PlayStation 5 console from China to other countries, significantly reducing the estimated impact of the tariffs over the last three months. We believe the outlook for Sony's US operations hinges less on tariffs than on the economy, although the entertainment sector is relatively resilient to fluctuations in the business cycle. Overall, we estimate the tariffs will reduce consolidated profits by less than \(10\%\) . With respect to US investment, Sony has actively engaged in M&A activity in the past and we expect it to continue efforts to expand its library of entertainment IP. We will be watching to see if the company can flexibly adjust its business strategy to undertake large acquisitions.

Panasonic has recently been expanding its US operations and has built a battery factory, established a US software subsidiary, and begun manufacturing in- flight entertainment systems. The impact of tariffs is spread broadly across its multiple businesses and we do not think it is large enough to affect the outlook of any single operation. While there is potential for future capital investment or M&A activity in the US, Panasonic's low valuations and RoIC, combined with its limited financial resources, mean it is unlikely to contribute significantly to Japan's ¥80trn investment in the US.

We expect Fuji Electric's power semiconductor business will benefit from the reduced \(15\%\) tariff rate. At Renesas Electronics, semiconductors produced for the Japanese market may be positively affected, but we do not anticipate a significant change in North American automotive demand. We think a separate examination of the \(100\%\) tariff on semiconductors is necessary (see below).

Fuji Electric exports power generation equipment to the US but expects to be able to pass on higher costs to customers, resulting in a neutral overall impact for the tariffs. A potential increase in Toyota's production of electric vehicles (including hybrids) should help boost Fuji Electric's supply of power semiconductors to the automaker. The vacuum interrupters that Meidensha exports to the US are a growth driver of the firm's North American operations, and the outlook appears to be improving. Socionext supplies semiconductors for digital cameras and automotive applications to domestic customers and is likely to be minimally affected by the reduction in tariffs.

Among Japanese semiconductor companies, we expect Renesas Electronics (which makes MCUs, SoCs, analog devices, and so on) to see a direct impact from the tariffs. Sony Group may also lose some of its share of the image sensor market due to a changing competitive environment. We project a reduced sector- specific tariff rate of \(15\%\) will be imposed on exports from Japan. Meanwhile, TSMC and Samsung Electronics have announced investments in the US, and semiconductors produced at these foundries will reportedly be exempt from tariffs. Renesas, which uses TSMC, may therefore see a reduced impact, while Socionext is expected to be largely unaffected. Some of the power semiconductors produced in Japan by Fuji Electric and Mitsubishi Electric are exported for automotive use, but we expect

OEMs and Tier 1 suppliers to bear the higher costs. If Samsung starts supplying semiconductors from its Texas factory, they may replace some of the image sensors that Sony currently supplies to Apple (see our report Samsung Electronics (005930. KS) - Apple Announces a Partnership with Samsung Foundry for US Supply Chain Expansion). It remains unclear whether the US will also impose tariffs on imports of finished and semi- finished electronic devices.

Precision equipment — The shift of office equipment production away from China has progressed significantly, with numerous factories being newly built in (or relocated to) Southeast Asian countries such as Vietnam, Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia over the past 5- 10 years. Relatively few products are still manufactured in China for export to the US. Precision equipment manufacturers, whether in Japan or in Southeast Asia, have raised prices on US- bound products to offset the additional tariff costs, with price hikes being implemented gradually starting this June. In April we were concerned about a potential decline in US demand due to these increases, but there was no surge in demand prior to the price hikes (and thus no notable drop afterwards), and as of August 2025, the impact on demand for copiers, printers, cameras, and similar products appears to be limited.

Semiconductor production equipment (SPE) — The main factories and supply chains of Japanese manufacturers in this sector are all in Japan, and the US accounts for only about \(10\%\) of total sales. We do not currently expect the US to impose additional tariffs on imports of SME. Even if such tariffs were applied, this kind of equipment is typically sold on a free on board (FoB) basis, meaning the buyer (semiconductor manufacturers) would bear the cost of the tariffs. If the push to expand semiconductor production in the US gains momentum, shipments of SPE to the country would probably increase as well, and we do not think the US would impose high additional tariffs on equipment needed to enhance domestic production capacity. In our view, the outlook for SPE suppliers is likely to hinge less on US tariffs than on whether Japan decides to tighten export controls on equipment shipped to mainland China.

Possibility of investment in US — Precision equipment manufacturers have few products expected to drive significant top- line growth and have invested little in expanding production outside the US (e.g., in Japan or Southeast Asia). We therefore do not expect them to announce plans for new factories. One exception is Fujifilm, which has been actively investing in US production in recent years via its bio- CDMO and semiconductor materials businesses. The company is building a new bio- CDMO plant in North Carolina, with the first phase of investment set to be completed when the factory goes online this autumn. We think Japanese makers of SPE are unlikely to pursue capital investments in the US given the concentration of their component and material suppliers in Japan.

Many Japanese producers of electronic components export relatively few products directly to the US and will therefore benefit only modestly from the reduced tariff rate. However, we see positive implications for two companies: 1) Niterra, which performs front- end processes for spark plugs domestically and exports to the US, and 2) GS Yuasa, which had initially expected the tariffs to reduce its shipments of industrial batteries and power supplies to North America. The global cuts in US tariffs have also fueled expectations for upward revisions to Kyocera's targets for

FY3/26. The company had originally forecast a ¥17bn decline in OP, primarily related to printer exports from Vietnam to the US. There was only a modest pickup in electronic component demand in the Apr- Jun quarter prior to the imposition of tariffs. We project a seasonal boost to sales—particularly of high- end smartphone components—in the Jul- Sep quarter. Moving forward, we think the key focus will be on whether the smaller- than- expected impact of tariffs has a positive impact on final demand.

We believe a significant number of Japanese companies will invest in the US over the next five to ten years, driven by a renewed sense of mission and support from the Japanese government (in the form of financing, debt guarantees, and so on). The possibility that US tariffs will continue under the next administration, as well as the desire to keep up with competitors, will provide incentives to invest in the US. In the industrial and consumer electronics sectors, Hitachi and Sony stood out in our screening for such factors as corporate size, the importance of their US operations, and their track record of executing on large M&A projects. We view these two companies as the only ones capable of securing trillion- yen M&A deals, publicly committing to significant business investment and job creation in the US through the acquired entities, and being rewarded by the equity market for the acquisition PER and post- acquisition RoIC of the acquisition targets. Mitsubishi Electric, Fujitsu, and Panasonic are also showing signs of stepping up their M&A efforts, increasing related budgets, and making sustained investments in existing US growth businesses. These companies fall into the second tier of our classification.

The electronic components sector currently has a great deal of supply capacity in many areas due to past capital investment and expanded production by Chinese competitors. Investments aimed at capturing demand from "de- Chinafied" supply chains are primarily focused on Southeast Asia, with no new investments seen in the US. KAVX, Kyocera's US capacitor subsidiary, says it is currently taking a wait- and- see approach on capacity expansion. But we think that Nidec, which has seen strong demand for its alternators in US data centers, may increase its capex over a longer- term, 5- to- 10- year time frame. Nidec generally seeks to produce locally in the markets where it is active. Additionally, if the market for TDK's secondary batteries for energy storage systems (ESS) grows to the extent that US production facilities are needed, the company may pursue such investments. In the precision machinery sector, we think Fujifilm is a potential candidate for large- scale investments—most likely a CDMO plant. It has already committed to investing more than \(\) 3bn\(, and we believe an additional\) \ \(3bn -\) 4bn is possible. However, this would be for US production and supply of biopharmaceuticals, not electrical machinery. We do not expect Japanese makers of SPE to undertake capital investments in the US given the concentration of their component and material suppliers in Japan.

SoftBank Group (SBG) has announced the Stargate Project, which will involve developing Al data centers in collaboration with Open Al and other firms. Although there have been few indications of concrete progress, we expect this massive project, with investments totaling \(\) 500bn\(over four years, will start to take shape over time.

SBG announced in January 2025 that the Stargate Project would invest \(\) 500bn\(over the next four years to build new Al infrastructure in the US. Initial equity investors are SBG, OpenAl, Oracle, and investment firm MGX, with SBG and OpenAl serving as lead partners. Arm, Microsoft, and Nvidia are listed as key initial technology partners, indicating that SBG is likely to play a key role in the development of US Al infrastructure.

While the details are not yet clear, the \(\) 500bn\$ is likely to be leveraged investment raised via equity contributions coupled with project finance and other external debt funding. This is because the investment case is well above SBG's cash savings and because we think external funds will be easy to raise as it is relatively straightforward to calculate data center cashflow. SBG's direct investment may account for only a few percent of the \(\) 500bn\$ , but the project is expected to contribute significantly to the buildup of Al infrastructure in the US. SBG announced in January 2025 that \(\) 100bn\$ of the \(\) 500bn\$ would be deployed immediately in locations such as Texas, where site selection was already underway.

The Stargate Project is essentially a group of data centers designed expressly for Al, with the potential to generate stable cash flow once operational. However, we believe SBG's goal is not to seek returns directly from the Stargate Project but rather to benefit from growth in OpenAI's business and the resulting increase in its enterprise value.

SBG has already invested \(\) 7.5bn\(in OpenAI and plans to add another\) \ \(22.5bn\) by the end of this year for a total of \(\) 30bn\(, giving OpenAI a"pre - money valuation" of\) \ \(260bn\) . After including the \(\) 11bn\(in other syndicated investments, we estimate that SBG will own\) \leq 10\% \(of the company's shares. Rather than focusing on returns from the Stargate Project itself, we think SBG will be able to achieve significant returns via growth in OpenAI's enterprise value.

SBG is also pursuing investments in other US companies. It has been investing in overseas businesses, including some in the US, through the SoftBank Vision Fund (SVF). It also has plans to acquire Ampere Computing, a US company, for \(\) 6.5bn\(by the end of the year. While the actual size of its Stargate Project commitment remains unclear, SBG's investments in OpenAI and Ampere alone will total\) \ \(36.5bn\) in 2025, marking it one of the largest corporate investors in the US. SBG is thus playing a central role in fulfilling Japan's US investment pledge.

NTT is also actively expanding its overseas operations, and Recruit Holdings appears to be exploring M&A options to strengthen its Indeed business. SBG is a key investor in the US telecommunications and internet sector, but large corporations like NTT and Recruit that are expanding their overseas operations are also expected to contribute to Japan's US investment pledge.

The direct and indirect impacts of tariffs on the chemical sector appear to be minimal so far. Companies exporting to the US seem to be making smooth progress in negotiations to pass on the cost of the tariffs, with customers often agreeing to bear the costs, particularly for high value- added products like semiconductor materials. While there was a modest pre- tariff bump in demand for North American smartphone materials and components, we do not anticipate a significant decline in reaction.

In terms of US investments, Shin- Etsu Chemical in 2024 submitted an application to the state of Louisiana for construction permits that would allow it to expand production of PVC. However, the timing of this project is unlikely to be brought forward within the context of tariffs.

There is also potential for an acceleration of US investment in fields such as life science (CDMO) and EV battery materials, although as yet there are no obvious indications of a shift in companies' investment stances.

The medtech tariff burden now seems likely to be lighter than initially expected and sector share prices are rising. An announcement for pharma, which is outside the scope of the current round of tariffs, is expected during August (Japan Pharmaceuticals and MedTech - Developments in pharma tariffs, one of three key risks: postponement and high rate). Pharma share prices are on a rebound, driven by names that have been sold off. Tariffs on pharma may be low in the short term but steep when firms have had time to shift production to the US, and this has caught market attention. We think a formal announcement will largely draw a line under negative tariff news for pharma. The next potential focus is the drug price cuts said to be taking shape in the US.

Takeda, the only company to refer to US investment when reporting March year- end results, spoke of \(\) 3bn\(. However, management explained that this includes marketing spend and is not a new plan; no new plant construction is involved. Unrelated to tariffs, Kyowa Kirin previously decided on\) \ \(530m\) total investment in biopharma plant construction in the US. Construction is underway, with a completion target of 2027. Given that construction takes around three years, it may be hard to embark on new plant investment without a perspective that extends beyond the Trump administration.

However, both pharma and medtech companies have retained their enthusiasm for M&A and we do not expect change here. Most targets are US start- up businesses. Big firms from Japan, the US, and Europe are seeking opportunities in world- leading US innovation. Recent deals include Astellas (acquisition of Iveric Bio for \(\) 800bn\(, 2023), Ono (Deciphera,\) \ \(380bn, 2024), and Otsuka Holdings (Jnana,\) \ \(120bn, 2024)\) and we assume more will follow. Firms that have disclosed M&A plans include Shionogi (total budget of \(\) 350bn\() and Terumo (targeting large deals).
Major homebuilders are keen to expand in the US. Sekisui House bought MDC Holdings in 2024 (¥800bn) and Daiwa House is among firms that have grown via multiple acquisitions.

The US housing market is rather weak at present but companies like the longer- term growth potential in a market with housing shortages created by reduced starts after the global financial crisis and population growth driven by immigration. We assume non- linear growth centered on builders.

In real estate, Mitsui Fudosan, Mitsubishi Estate, and Tokyo Fudosan are also among the early investors and now steady growth is underway in investment by firms like Nomura Real Estate, Tokyo Tatemono, and Hulic. There are differences in degree but investment stances are generally proactive. High interest rates have slowed the trading market in the US and there are moves to expand investment in readiness for a market recovery and improvement in leasing supply/demand when interest rates come down. Other than the New York flagship offices of Mitsui Fudosan and Mitsubishi Estate, investment centers on rental housing and logistics facilities. Mitsui Fudosan is investing aggressively in rental housing with an eye on future declines in construction starts in this category. Mitsubishi Estate is pushing ahead with data center investment using local subsidiary TA Realty, taking equity stakes of around ¥150bn, and we expect investments to be increased.

Citi Research stock recommendations include an investment rating and an optional risk rating to highlight high risk stocks. Risk rating takes into account both price volatility and fundamental criteria. Stocks will either have no risk rating or a High risk rating assigned.

Investment Ratings: Citi Research investment ratings are Buy, Neutral and Sell. Our ratings are a function of analyst expectations of expected total return ("ETR") and risk. ETR is the sum of the forecast price appreciation (or depreciation) plus the dividend yield for a stock within the next 12 months. The target price is based on a 12 month time horizon. The Investment rating definitions are: Buy (1) ETR of \(15\%\) or more or \(25\%\) or more for High risk stocks; and Sell (3) for negative ETR. Any covered stock not assigned a Buy or a Sell is a Neutral (2). For stocks rated Neutral (2), if an analyst believes that there are insufficient valuation drivers and/or investment catalysts to derive a positive or negative investment view, they may elect with the approval of Citi Research management not to assign a target price and, thus, not derive an ETR. Citi Research may suspend its rating and target price and assign "Rating Suspended" status for regulatory and/or internal policy reasons. Citi Research may also suspend its rating and target price and assign "Under Review" status for other exceptional circumstances (e.g. lack of information critical to the analyst's thesis, trading suspension) affecting the company and/or trading in the company's securities. In both such situations, the rating and target price will show as "—" and "—" respectively in the rating history price chart. Prior to 11 April 2022 Citi Research assigned "Under Review" status to both situations and prior to 11 Nov 2020 only in exceptional circumstances. As soon as practically possible, the analyst will publish a note re-establishing a rating and investment thesis. Investment ratings are determined by the ranges described above at the time of initiation of coverage, a change in investment and/or risk rating, or a change in target price (subject to limited management discretion). At times, the expected total returns may fall outside of these ranges because of market price movements and/or other short-term volatility or trading patterns. Such interim deviations will be permitted but will become subject to review by Research Management. Your decision to buy or sell a security should be based upon your personal investment objectives and should be made only after evaluating the stock's expected performance and risk.

Catalyst Watch and STV Upside/Downside calls: Citi Research may also include a Catalyst Watch or STV Upside or Downside call to indicate the analyst expects the share price to rise (fall) in absolute terms over a specified period of 30 or 90 days in

reaction to one or more specific near- term catalysts or events impacting the company or the market. A Catalyst Watch will be published when Analyst confidence is high that an impact to share price will occur; it will be a STV when confidence level is moderate. A Catalyst Watch or STV Upside/Downside call will automatically expire at the end of the specified 30/90 day period. The Catalyst Watch will also be automatically removed if share price performance (calculated at market close) exceeds \(15\%\) against the direction of the call (unless over- ridden by the analyst). The analyst may also remove a Catalyst Watch or STV call prior to the end of the specified period in a published research note. A Catalyst Watch/STV Upside or Downside call may be different from and does not affect a stock's fundamental equity rating, which reflects a longer- term total absolute return expectation. For purposes of FINRA ratings- distribution- disclosure rules, a Catalyst Watch/STV Upside call corresponds to a buy recommendation and a Catalyst Watch/STV Downside call corresponds to a sell recommendation. Any stock not assigned to a Catalyst Watch Upside, Catalyst Watch Downside, STV Upside, or STV Downside call is considered Catalyst Watch/STV No View. For purposes of FINRA ratings distribution- disclosure rules, we correspond Catalyst Watch/STV No View to Hold in our ratings distribution table for our Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside rating system. However, we reiterate that we do not consider No View to be a recommendation. For all Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside calls, risk exists that the catalyst(s) and associated share- price movement will not materialize as expected.
